AT MUSICAL CLUB
MEETING
Manager Vanneman Announces
Varied Schedule. Conductor
Being Sought for Organization
Sixty-three men possessing musical talent reported at the first
meeting of the Musical Club on
Monday night. Many of the men
were Freshmen, possessing unknown talents. Some of the older
nen, however, are expected to ap)ear later.

LOST AND FOUND
Among the numerous services rendered by the University Y. M.
C. A., the Lost and Found Bureau, established several years ago, has
become a vital part of the campus life and has functioned most successfully.
As has been pointed out by the Student Council, the Honor System
extends not only to class-room work, but every action at the University
which involves the question of honesty. "Findin's keepin's" has become
too much of a good thing in the outside world. The appropriation of
trifles of low value has oftimes led to keeping things of greater value.
Last year the Bureau found the owners of hundreds of articles,
from fancy pins to furs. Books that were formerly stowed away in the
finder's bookcase found their rightful owners through this medium.
Notes are frequently found which are valueless to the finder, but
are priceless to the owner. To return such an article to the Bureau
requires but a few minutes and may save the owner a great deal of
anxiety and trouble.

In any one year the membership
of the society must not exceed three
per cent, of the total number of undergraduates in the University. It
is a fact that membership here at
Hopkins has never approached the
three per cent, limit and at present
consists of only five members.
Membership in 0. D. K. is not

for the purpose of spurring its
members to even greater . activity,
both individually and collectively,
for the good of the University. Its
members are_.bound to,_ -put their

for Hopkins, and have done so ever
since its foundation here. The possibility, of being chosen as a member of 0. D. K. should be an inspiration for every Hopkins man,

ELECTRICAL CLUB TO FORM
ALUMNI ASSOCIATION
The electrical Club held its first
meeting last Friday, October 6, in
the M. and E. Building. President
Wm. T. Alderson, acting on the
suggestion of Dean Whitehead,
proposed plans for forming an
alumni association. He emphasized that many graduate engineers
are engaged in interesting occupations, and that a close association
with these men would promote a

A stove burns too much coal. A man familiar with
the principles of combustion and heat radiation
makes experiments which indicate desirable changes
in design. That is research.
You want to make a ruby in a factory, a real ruby,
indistinguishable by any test from the natural stone.
You begin by analyzing rubies chemically and physically. Then you make rubies just as nature did.
Your rubies are the result of research—another type
of research.
While melting up your chemicals and experimenting
with high temperatures, you begin to wonder how
hot the earth must have been millions of years ago,
and what were the forces at play that made this
planet what it is. Your investigation leads you far
from rubies and causes you to formulate theories to
explain how the earth, how the whole solar system
was created. That would be research of a still different type.
Research of all three types is conducted in the laboratories of the General Electric Company. But it is
the third type—pioneering into the unknown—that
means most in the long run, even though undertaken
with no practical benefit in view.
For example, the Research Laboratories of the
General Electric Company arc exploring matter with
X-rays in order to discover not only how the atoms
in different substances are arranged but how the
atoms themselves are built up. The more you know
about a substance, the more you can do with it. This
work may enable scientists to answer more definitely
the question: Why is iron magnetic? Then the electrical industry will take a greater step forward than
can be made in a century of experimenting with
existing electrical apparatus.
You can add wings and stories to an old house. But
to build a new house, you must begin with the
foundation.

SAVINGS PLAN FOR HAVERFORD GAME ANNOUNCED
The Publicity Board is back of
a plan to help student rooters get
to the Haverford game. • Within
the next few days savings stamps in
the denominations of 25 Or 50
cents will be sold at the University
postoffice. These stamps must be
attached to cards provided for the
purpose, and when a sufficient
amount in stamps has been attached
the card may be exchanged for a
round-trip ticket to Haverford.
This is the first time any such
plan has been attempted at Hopkins ,and the Publicity Board is
anxious that as many students as
possible take advantage of this opportunity to support the football
team.

semi-popular constitutes ..highbrowism," then we admit the
accusation.
QUEER? Yes, if by queer you mean the constant doing of things

DULL? Certainly, if your standard of values is based on the appreciation of Snappy Stories and Telling Tales.
MORBID ? Perhaps, that depends—all of our stories certainly do

DEGENERATE? Possibly—but wouldn't you like to be associated with the following company of degenerates, all of whom

Mr Anderson is the most interesting and important figure in
contemporary American letters. Since his arrival six years
ago, Mr Anderson has published six books, each of which
has marked a distinct growth in this development. His latest
work to be published in book form is The Triumph of the
Egg, a collection of his best short stories. This was probably
the most seriously discussed book of the past year.
MANY MARRIAGES, his latest novel, both in theme and
treatment, stands far apart from the run of novels dealing
with the American scene. The confident belief held by
American and foreign critics in Mr Anderson's future will
be justified by this new novel, for in it he has gone farther
than in any previous work in the full development of his
art. A man living in a small town in the State of Wisconsin is the central character of this significant work. It is
the story of the love and marriage of a man,told as the man
understands it on the decisive night when the marriage
comes to an end. The intensity of emotion and the richness
of imagination are equally remarkable. This novel marks
a distinct break from the methods of photographic realism
so much in vogue among writers of the middle west. It is
the most important work that Mr Anderson has produced
so far, and is certain to be acclaimed by the discriminating
as a permanent contribution to American letters.

LOST AND FOUND
Among the numerous services rendered by the University Y. M.
C. A., the Lost and Found Bureau, established several years ago, has
become a vital part of the campus life and has functioned most successfully.
As has been pointed out by the Student Council, the Honor System
extends not only to class-room work, but every action at the University
which involves the question of honesty. "Findin's keepin's" has become
too much of a good thing in the outside world. The appropriation of
trifles of low value has oftimes led to keeping things of greater value.
Last year the Bureau found the owners of hundreds of articles,
from fancy pins to furs. Books that were formerly stowed away in the
finder's bookcase found their rightful owners through this medium.
Notes are frequently found which are valueless to the finder, but
are priceless to the owner. To return such an article to the Bureau
requires but a few minutes and may save the owner a great deal of
anxiety and trouble.

ELECTRICAL CLUB TO FORM
ALUMNI ASSOCIATION
The electrical Club held its first
meeting last Friday, October 6, in
the M. and E. Building. President
Wm. T. Alderson, acting on the
suggestion of Dean Whitehead,
proposed plans for forming an
alumni association. He emphasized that many graduate engineers
are engaged in interesting occupations, and that a close association
with these men would promote a
better understanding of actual conditions in the electrical profession.
A committee was appointed to investigate and perfect the proposed
plan. Discussions of the ability
and character of the several Junior
Electrical Engineers who may be
invited to join the organization
brought the meeting to a close. In
view of the unusual positions held
by many of the present club members during the past summer, many
interesting and instructive lectures
are anticipated. The next meeting
will be held Friday, October 13, at
4:15, and a talk will be made by
Mr. White.

A stove burns too much coal. A man familiar with
the principles of combustion and heat radiation
makes experiments which indicate desirable changes
in design. That is research.
You want to make a ruby in a factory, a real ruby,
indistinguishable by any test from the natural stone.
You begin by analyzing rubies chemically and physically. Then you make rubies just as nature did.
Your rubies are the result of research—another type
of research.
While melting up your chemicals and experimenting
with high temperatures, you begin to wonder how
hot the earth must have been millions of years ago,
and what were the forces at play that made this
planet what it is. Your investigation leads you far
from rubies and causes you to formulate theories to
explain how the earth, how the whole solar system
was created. That would be research of a still different type.
Research of all three types is conducted in the laboratories of the General Electric Company. But it is
the third type—pioneering into the unknown—that
means most in the long run, even though undertaken
with no practical benefit in view.
For example, the Research Laboratories of the
General Electric Company arc exploring matter with
X-rays in order to discover not only how the atoms
in different substances are arranged but how the
atoms themselves are built up. The more you know
about a substance, the more you can do with it. This
work may enable scientists to answer more definitely
the question: Why is iron magnetic? Then the electrical industry will take a greater step forward than
can be made in a century of experimenting with
existing electrical apparatus.
You can add wings and stories to an old house. But
to build a new house, you must begin with the
foundation.

SAVINGS PLAN FOR HAVERFORD GAME ANNOUNCED
The Publicity Board is back of
a plan to help student rooters get
to the Haverford game. • Within
the next few days savings stamps in
the denominations of 25 Or 50
cents will be sold at the University
postoffice. These stamps must be
attached to cards provided for the
purpose, and when a sufficient
amount in stamps has been attached
the card may be exchanged for a
round-trip ticket to Haverford.
This is the first time any such
plan has been attempted at Hopkins ,and the Publicity Board is
anxious that as many students as
possible take advantage of this opportunity to support the football
team.

semi-popular constitutes ..highbrowism," then we admit the
accusation.
QUEER? Yes, if by queer you mean the constant doing of things
other magazines never think of.
DULL? Certainly, if your standard of values is based on the appreciation of Snappy Stories and Telling Tales.
MORBID ? Perhaps, that depends—all of our stories certainly do
not have happy endings.
DEGENERATE? Possibly—but wouldn't you like to be associated with the following company of degenerates, all of whom

Mr Anderson is the most interesting and important figure in
contemporary American letters. Since his arrival six years
ago, Mr Anderson has published six books, each of which
has marked a distinct growth in this development. His latest
work to be published in book form is The Triumph of the
Egg, a collection of his best short stories. This was probably
the most seriously discussed book of the past year.
MANY MARRIAGES, his latest novel, both in theme and
treatment, stands far apart from the run of novels dealing
with the American scene. The confident belief held by
American and foreign critics in Mr Anderson's future will
be justified by this new novel, for in it he has gone farther
than in any previous work in the full development of his
art. A man living in a small town in the State of Wisconsin is the central character of this significant work. It is
the story of the love and marriage of a man,told as the man
understands it on the decisive night when the marriage
comes to an end. The intensity of emotion and the richness
of imagination are equally remarkable. This novel marks
a distinct break from the methods of photographic realism
so much in vogue among writers of the middle west. It is
the most important work that Mr Anderson has produced
so far, and is certain to be acclaimed by the discriminating
as a permanent contribution to American letters.
